text: Hello, everyone.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: My name is Navid Hakimi, and I'm very glad to be joined here by Professor Chatter and Dr. McKay from
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Warwick Institute and Mathematics Institute in the UK.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And they're going to talk about thermal macroeconomics, a thermodynamic approach to economics.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the first part of the talk would be them going through the presentation and then
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: hopefully we're going to have time to ask some questions and ask their opinion about the mapping between their concepts and active inference and also more maybe general questions about macroeconomics so very glad and very excited for the talk and i give the mic to dr mckay right so in fact nick here's i'm going to start off
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: a brief sort of conceptual outline um and then um robert is going to give a a little more detailed technical summary and i should say that um i wish i was at the mathematical mathematics institute at work because it's a very grand place to be um but i'm not that mathematical so i'm i'm in the behavioral science group at or at business school and a behavioral scientist by background
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And in fact, it's probably a good place to start actually, because an interesting question for people interested in economics from a behavioural point of view is how do we make sense of economic theory as it's currently practised
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: which assumes, for theoretical reasons, extremely rational and sophisticated agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They often have perfect knowledge and perfect calculating abilities, and they do perfect Bayesian inference, and they maximize some utility, each one.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then we put those agents together and explain aggregate phenomena as a kind of complicated outcome of all those extremely rational agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the behavioral spin on that is always, well, yes, but people aren't really like that, are they?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: and you get all kinds of irrationalities at the individual level, and perhaps some of those lead to a group level of rationalities as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So, for example, booms and busts through herding and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But the basic problem for trying to found an economic theory
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: is that if it turns out that the agents that we're working with are much, much more heterogeneous and complicated and not as rational as in standard theory, does that invalidate or at least throw into question standard economic theory?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So an interesting
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: strategy to assuage that worry, which is roughly where Robert and I have been going, although there are a variety of motivations you might use for this approach, but this is one of them, is to say, well, hang on, at the aggregate level, maybe economies can work in quite a predictable way, even if the individual elements within them are extremely complicated and heterogeneous.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And in fact, we sort of have to believe that because real economists don't really think
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: that players in markets are perfectly informed about all possible outside options and have a perfect understanding of the implications of all their choices.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It's just clearly not the case.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And yes, at least on the face of it, basic economic principles seem to be reasonably applicable to the real world.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So it seems like you have to really have some belief that there's a way of understanding the aggregate phenomena without understanding micro-foundations in any great deal, because they're just too complicated to understand.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then a natural parallel that comes to mind, it's not come to mind to us uniquely, because this has been something that people thought about forever, sort of at least a century, probably more, is the thought that, well, in physics,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: you can say all kinds of aggregate things about, for example, the temperatures and pressures and so on, without really understanding the micro foundations terribly well.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Indeed, of course, classical thermodynamics arose before people had any real idea about micro foundations and I think weren't too sure about whether the atomic theory was correct and really basic things like this.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So it turns out to be possible, at least in the physical context, to have an aggregate theory without really understanding the micro foundations you're working with.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: and of course then it turned out later of course that at least for certain systems like very simple gases you can figure out micro foundations and miraculously everything sort of fits together the micro foundations and macro story can be beautifully aligned which is an extraordinary scientific discovery.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But of course, the concepts of classical thermodynamics still apply to all kinds of complicated things like human bodies and so on, which are where the micro-foundations are extremely difficult.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So if you're trying to apply thermodynamics to biological systems, you're going to struggle with micro-foundations, but still, my body has a well-defined temperature and so on, to some extent anyway.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So the thought is, can we, and this is, as I say, not a unique thought to us, can we understand the aggregate properties of economies
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: with that understanding of micro-foundations, just as is possible in the physical case.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And of course, the dream scenario would be there's some direct mapping, some sort of natural mapping from one case to the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And this is, again, something that people have thought about for at least a century, because they've seen so many intuitive connections.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So it feels like something where there ought to be a possible connection and people have struggled to make that connection rigorous.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And what we've tried to do is to see if we can make that connection rigorous.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the only other thing I want to say is that one reason that we took the approach we did is that we were inspired by a very interesting work on the axiomatic foundations of thermodynamics by Lieb and Ingverson.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the great thing about their approach is that they have a very clear mathematical, they sort of lay out the mathematical principles which underlie classical thermodynamics in a way that doesn't require any reference to any physical notions.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You don't have to worry about heat or temperature or work or anything.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You just have this mathematical structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And indeed, they say in their papers that this structure of principle could apply to other things.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: what struck us many years ago now is that, well, if there is a mapping to be created between these two domains, economics and thermodynamics, then that abstract mathematical structure that they've created ought to be transferable.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And that's the starting point for the approach is to try to make that leap.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I think if we
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It's taken us a long time to get there, but we, I think, do have a fairly firm understanding, at least the simple cases of how that works now.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So I'll hand over to Robert for a more technical talk, but at least I'll hopefully give listeners some sense of why we're trying to do this.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Of course, I should also say just very briefly that the hope is both to reconstruct some aspects of existing economic theory,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The dream scenario would be able to go beyond that, to use this method to explain systems that can't really be explained in conventional terms, so that one actually has a richer theory, or at least a complementary theory to existing approaches.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But with that, I will stop and hand over to Robert.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Thanks, Nick.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So yeah, I'll present some of our theory, but also some tests by simulations that have been done by our student Yihang Luo.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we deal with what are called exchange economies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: These are a very standard concept in at least economic theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You'll find this in any textbook.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: in economics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the idea is that we have a large, finite, fixed number of agents and we have a finite number of types of durable, infinitely divisible good.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: One of them we call money.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And agents repeatedly exchange goods in encounters
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: According to some physicists, we'd say rules, but just some behavioral characteristics, say, the key assumption we make is that this dynamics is assumed to lead to convergence of probabilities, at least for the allocation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we're not
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We're not asking for the process to terminate with some, in quotes, optimal allocation, but we are asking for process to converge to some probability distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So individual allocation will keep hopping around, but the probability distribution will be a fixed one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We start with what we call basic economies, so ones with no barriers, so that a part of good could, in principle, transfer from any of the agents to any of the other agents via perhaps a long route.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And for these, we assume convergence to a unique equilibrium.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So equilibrium, again, means a probability distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's not a fixed allocation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Unique given the total amounts of each type of good.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So obviously the types of good we're supposing are conserved.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we get different equilibria as you change the amounts of good.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But we're really interested in multi-part economies, so where goods of some types are constrained to some subsets of agents, which we call components.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Just think of an economy that lives on two islands, and maybe some goods can't be transferred from one of the islands to the other, but other goods can, and maybe money can.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So again, we'll assume conversions to unique equilibrium, but now specifying the total amount of each type of good isn't enough because the amount of good on one island can't change either.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we need to specify a bit more.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then the question is what happens if one removes some barriers or puts two or more economies in some form of contact, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So suppose it becomes possible to move the good from one island to the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this one can regard as a basic question in economics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we have an answer, which is very different from standard economics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Our answer is that under some axioms, and one significant one that I highlight is extensivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we assume that there's some scaling symmetry of economic systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: then each economy has a concave, twice-differentiable entropy function, we call it S, of its state, so the state is given by the amounts of money and goods in the various components that I talked about, such that when you put economies in contact, the total entropy cannot decrease, and any outcome that increases the total entropy is possible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: until you reach a final outcome that maximizes the total entropy, then there's nowhere else to go.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Contrast this with standard economics, where no economy would want to reduce its utility.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if we think of this entropy as maybe like a utility.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the final outcome would be a Pareto optimal allocation accessible from the initial endowment, which wouldn't necessarily maximize the total utility.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is the basic answer, but I'm going to go through a list of further consequences and illustrate them by Yang's simulations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the first consequence is that each economy has a financial temperature.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is actually given by the reciprocal of the partial derivative of the entropy with respect to the amount of money in the economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And on financial contact, money flows from hotter to cooler.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is part of why we call our approach thermal economics, because we do have a concept of temperature.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Each good, say, type I in an economy, has a marginal value, mu I, which is just given by this partial derivative.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the economy buys from or sells to an external trader according as the trader's price is below or above what we call market price, mu I, for the good, which is the temperature times this value.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we predict which way goods would flow if some external trader says, OK, I'm willing to buy or sell at such and such a price.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Next consequence is we can make money out of temperature differences.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is basically by making what's in physics called Carnot cycles.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And funnily enough, I'm in Dijon at the moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I'm in the Mathematics Institute, but right next door is the Institut Carnot de Bourgogne in physics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Maxwell, yeah, another consequence is we get relations between partial derivatives, like, for example, that the partial derivative of the value of the i-th type of good with respect to the amount of the j-th is symmetric.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: respect to interchanging i and j. In physics, these would be called Maxwell relations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In economics, at the level of individual agents, such relations are called Hotelling relations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's the same mathematics, if you like.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it's due to the fact that the entropy is twice differentiable, and you get a symmetry of second derivatives.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We also deduce, because of the law of non-decrease of entropy, non-negativity of various partial derivatives and matrices of partial derivatives.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And furthermore, we get inequalities between derivatives subject to... We can do derivatives with respect to constant amounts, as I've talked about here, or with respect to constant prices.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Okay, so that's maybe a lot to take hold of.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But to make it a bit more concrete.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We tested the ideas on some simulated economies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the simplest type that we used what we call Cobb Douglas economies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Each agent has what we'll call a utility function that is used differently from standard economics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Cobb Douglas utility is this product of powers, the amount of money
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: to a power e to minus one times the amount of goods to a power alpha minus one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And on parallelized encounters, they pool their belongings and they redistribute between themselves with a probability density that's proportional to the product of their utility functions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the idea is that this process will bias the outcome towards increasing utility for the two agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But there's the probability of one or other moving the wrong way.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And for this type of economy, we can prove convergence to equilibrium.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So there is a probability distribution for the allocation over the n agents that is stationary with respect to this process.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And whatever probability distribution you start with will converge to it as time goes to infinity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Furthermore, we can prove using basically the construction of the theorem of
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: for this case that the entropy has this formula.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's number of agents times log of the mean money per agent to the power eta times the mean goods per agent to the power alpha.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And from this, we can deduce what the temperature is.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So just by differentiating definition of temperature, it should be m over n times eta.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the price of the good, here I'm just supposing one type of good,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: as well as money, will be alpha m over e to g. So Yihang put two of these Cobb-Douglas economies in financial contact, one with an initial temperature of 50 and the other 100.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And he let them equilibrate, settle down a bit, and then put them in contact at this time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And you see that indeed the temperatures move together.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and we could have plotted how the money flows but the point is the money flows from the hotter to the cooler of course there are fluctuations here because the simulations are just for finite size whereas the theory is really for the thermodynamic limit of infinite size another simulation test we did was to put
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: a Cobb Douglas economy in contact with a trader offering to buy or sell the good at a given price.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we chose the amount of goods in the economy to be 500,000 and at this time put it in contact with the trader.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the blue curve is when the trader is offering a price of 0.9.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The market price initially is 1.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if the trader offers a price of 0.9,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Well, then the economy is going to say, oh, that's a good idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Let's buy lots of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The amount of goods in the economy is going to go up as we see this blue curve.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But then, of course, the situation in the economy has changed.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The market price will have decreased and it decreases to around 0.9 and then fluctuates around there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If the trader offers a price of one, well, then there's no significant initial movement.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The amount of goods fluctuates around here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And similarly, if the trader offered a price of 1.1, then the economy is going to say, oh, good, let's sell to the trader.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: OK, so there are two illustrations of the theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Another illustration is we can put two of these Cobb-Douglas economies in full contact, meaning we allow money and goods to flow between them.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here we've plotted horizontally as the amount of goods in the first economy and vertically the amount of money in the first economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the total amount is given by the opposite side of the square, if you like.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So our initial allocation, the first economy doesn't have many goods, but it has more money than the other one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we start here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we let them exchange.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The economies actually have different exponents in their Cobb-Douglas laws.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Just to show that doesn't matter.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the simulations trajectories look like this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: there is flow of money and goods from one to the other, and then it settles down around some point here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the contours in this picture are the contours of total entropy, the entropy of the two economies added together.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you see that the entropy increases to this maximum point.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Over here, we chose a different initial endowment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we get the same behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But the interesting thing in this is, again, to contrast with standard economics, what I've done here is to plot in orange the indifference curve for economy two and in blue indifference curve for economy one, meaning constant entropy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if we interpret entropy as a utility.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the standard analysis, which is called Edgeworth Box, would say that depending on the negotiating skills of the two economies, we'd end up somewhere on this Pareto frontier.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's where there's no way that one can benefit without the other losing something.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And indeed, the maximum entry point in this picture is in this interval of the Pareto frontier.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But over here, it isn't.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Edgeworth-Box would say that you go to some point up here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But when we put them in contact, they go here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: OK.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I mentioned that you can make money out of temperature differences.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So just to briefly describe that, let's suppose we have two economies, which I'll call hot and cold.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we have a ship economy that can shuttle between them.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the trader can trade just with the ship economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the trader can put the ship economy into financial contact with the hot or the cold mainland.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If we start here, total goods is horizontal.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we start with 4,000 goods on the ship and a temperature on the ship of 20.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then what the trader does,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: is to buy goods from the ship, which makes the amount of goods decrease.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We go up this blue curve.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Temperature goes up.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's because actually the amount of money on the ship is going up.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And because it's a Cobb Douglas economy, its temperature goes up.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it goes up until the temperature reaches 26, which is the temperature of the hot economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then the trader connects the ship economy to the hot economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: financially and decides to buy goods from the ship.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it buys goods from the ship and temperature on the ship fluctuates because there's a random process but basically around 26 there's some money flow also from the hot economy in order to maintain this temperature until a certain time when the trader decides to disconnect from the hot economy and carry on
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: selling goods to the ship.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We go down this red curve until the ship reaches the temperature of the cold, then we put in contact with the cold and buy goods from the ship until we get back to the beginning.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in this process, the trader makes a net amount of money and in some sense is given by the area of this suitably interpreted.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we verified that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Okay, maybe that was a bit long.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In this one, we take into account reality that the hot and cold mainlands aren't infinitely large.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So actually, as money flows out of the hot one, its temperature is going to decrease a bit.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And similarly, as money flows into the cold one, its temperature will go up a bit.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here we get a spiral instead.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Maybe I should just skip these things if they're too technical, but this was a simulation to illustrate the symmetry and negative definiteness of these partial derivatives.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we took what we call a substitutes economy, where there are two types of good, but the Asians only care about the total amount of the two types of good they have.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's why we call it a substitutes economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we also studied case of a compliments economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Again, two types of good.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The utility for an agent is given by the minimum of the amounts of good.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So one good is useless without a corresponding amount of the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And you can compute the entropy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Again, it's feasible to do this, but what we do is we use Cobb-Douglas economies as meters in the simulations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so we look at these partial derivatives and we see that indeed they're negative definite and pretty close to symmetry.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Another thing we do is putting economies in contact and look at the flow between them as a function of the value difference.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So actually, we do it the other way around because it's slightly easier to simulate and measure the value difference for given flow.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And again, we get some matrices representing this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the theory says they should be positive definite.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And indeed, that seems to be the case.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: As Nick started out by saying, a big motivation was to make a theory of macroeconomics that allows for real
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: behavioral agents rather than the economist's ideal rational maximizers.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we simulated one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is an example that we call Bouchot economy after Bouchot who inspired it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We suppose that the utility for agent I depends not just on their own money, MI, but also on the mean money that everyone else has.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So of course, if we just have one economy, the mean money is not going to change.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But if we put two of these in contact, then the mean can change.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so that's what we did here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We just again confirmed that if we take two Bouchot economies here and here, the yellow and blue with different initial temperatures and then put them in contact at time two, then their temperatures will converge together.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: More recently, one thing we've been doing is for
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: what we call calorimetry by an analogy of physics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you might say, okay, this theory is great, but for a complicated system, how on earth could I hope to know what the entropy function is?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But it's exactly like in physics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Even something like steam is too complicated to do theoretical calculations for the entropy as a function of, say, pressure and temperature.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what do the engineers do who run steam turbines, as my grandfather was?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They have steam tables, so they do lots of experiments, and they manage to deduce what the entropy function is by looking at how much heat is absorbed or given out in various changes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we do the same in economics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: For a real economic system, this may be rather difficult because you have to be allowed to mess with it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But for our simulated ones, it's easy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we measure the entropy by integrating this relation for the entropy with respect to money and goods.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the point is this integral is supposed to be path independent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the theory says.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And indeed, we check that and find it's nearly independent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we get a picture here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So there is a class of models, and this is something Navid was interested in, for which one can prove that the entropy is actually logarithm of some what's called partition function in statistical mechanics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so this connects the macro theory with micro.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But that's not fundamental to our analysis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: OK, so in principle, this would be a good test if one, I guess some people are big enough to be able to play with an economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We've seen notable examples.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if you're allowed to play, well, then you could try to measure the entropy function.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So a conclusion of this presentation, we've presented a thermodynamic theory of macroeconomics, at least in the context of extensive exchange economies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the main things we show that they have an entropy function and no interaction can decrease the total entropy.
